docs.title: 3270Web User Guide
docs.text: 3270Web is a browser-based IBM 3270 terminal client.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/tunlxio/tunlx/main/install.sh | bash

This guide focuses on daily use:

  • Connect to a host
  • Use terminal controls and keyboard shortcuts
  • Record, load, play, and debug workflows
  • Run chaos exploration and export generated workflow JSON
  • Configure settings from the UI

docs.title: First Session
docs.text:
1. Open 3270Web in your browser.
  2. Connect to your target TN3270 host.
  3. Use the terminal session normally.
  4. Optional: record and replay repeatable tasks.

docs.title: Chaos Mode
docs.text: Chaos mode explores host screens by filling input fields with generated values and submitting AID keys (Enter, Tab, PF*, and others). It is useful for discovering navigation paths and producing reusable workflow JSON.

docs.title: Start a Chaos Run
docs.text:
1. Connect to a host.
  2. Click Start chaos exploration in the toolbar.
  3. Watch run activity in:
  4. the toolbar (CHAOS indicator + stats), and
  5. the Workflow Status widget (attempts, writes, transitions, and errors).

docs.title: During the Run
docs.text:
Chaos mode continuously:

  • Reads the current screen
  • Writes generated values into unprotected fields
  • Sends an AID key
  • Records transition and attempt metadata

You can stop the run at any time with Stop chaos exploration.

docs.title: Completion Status
docs.text:
When chaos mode ends, the UI shows completed state:

  • CHAOS COMPLETE indicator in the toolbar
  • Final run statistics (steps, transitions, unique screens/inputs)
  • Completion details in the Workflow Status widget

This gives immediate confirmation that the run finished and data is ready for export.

docs.title: Download the JSON Output
docs.text:
After a run has data, click Download chaos workflow JSON in the toolbar.

  • The exported file is a workflow JSON compatible with workflow load/playback.
  • If a run ID is available, the filename includes it for easier future reference.

docs.title: Load and Resume Saved Runs
docs.text:
You can reuse previous chaos results:

  1. Click Load previous chaos run.
  2. Pick a saved run from the modal list.
  3. Optional: click Resume chaos exploration from loaded run to continue discovery.
  4. Export JSON again when done.

You can also seed chaos mode directly from a loaded recording:

  1. Load a recording in the recording section.
  2. Click Load recording into chaos in the chaos toolbar section.
  3. Start or resume chaos exploration.

When chaos output is saved, its filename is kept separate from the loaded recording filename to avoid overwriting the recording JSON.

docs.title: Chaos Hints
docs.text:
Chaos Hints let you guide generated input values during exploration.

  1. Click Edit chaos hints in the chaos toolbar.
  2. Add hint rows with:
  3. Transaction values (for example, known transaction codes), and/or
  4. Known data values (comma or newline separated).
  5. Optional: click Load from recording to import hint candidates from a previous recording JSON.
  6. Click Save hints to persist them.
  7. Use Load saved to reload persisted hints into the modal.

Notes:

  • Hints are saved to chaos-hints.json.
  • Saved hints are automatically applied when starting or resuming chaos if request-level hints are not explicitly supplied.
  • Transaction hints are preferred for early field writes, while known data values are reused across fields when they fit field constraints.

docs.title: Chaos Settings
docs.text:
Chaos behavior is configurable in Settings -> Chaos:

  • Max steps
  • Time budget
  • Step delay
  • Random seed
  • Max field length
  • Optional output file path
  • Exclude no-progress events (default on)

Use small limits first when testing new host flows, then increase limits for broader exploration.

docs.title: Connect and Use 3270Web
docs.text: This page explains connection setup and the full Settings modal from a user perspective.

docs.title: Connect to a Host
docs.text:
You can connect to:

  • hostname:port (example: mainframe.example.com:23)
  • IPv4:port (example: 10.0.0.5:23)
  • IPv6:port (example: [::1]:23)
  • sampleapp:<id> for bundled sample targets

If autoconnect is enabled, 3270Web will connect automatically on startup.

docs.title: Open Settings
docs.text:
1. Click the Settings icon in the toolbar.
  2. Use tabs to switch sections.
  3. Edit values.
  4. Click Save settings.
  5. If prompted, restart 3270Web to apply startup-level changes.

You can also use:

  • Refresh to reload current values
  • Reset to defaults inside each settings section
  • Maximize for easier editing of long values

docs.title: Toolbar Callouts
docs.text:
1. Disconnect
  2. Logs
  3. Settings
  4. Start recording
  5. View recording (when a recording is loaded)

docs.title: Settings Modal Callouts
docs.text:
1. Refresh values
  2. Maximize/restore modal
  3. Close settings
  4. Section tabs
  5. Active section content
  6. Reset section to defaults
  7. Save settings

docs.title: Connectivity
docs.text:
Controls how 3270Web reaches the host.

Includes:

  • Port, connect timeout
  • IPv4/IPv6 preference
  • Proxy settings
  • callback/script port and socket options

Use this section when you need alternate network routing or script protocol listeners.

docs.title: TLS/Security
docs.text:
Controls TLS certificate and protocol behavior.

Includes:

  • Certificate verification toggle
  • Min/max TLS protocol
  • Client certificate and key files
  • CA file/directory/chain
  • Accepted hostname and client certificate name

Use this when connecting to secured hosts with custom certificate requirements.

docs.title: Emulation
docs.text:
Controls terminal identity and data representation.

Includes:

  • Terminal model (3278/3279 variants)
  • Host code page
  • Terminal/device/user identity options
  • NVT mode and oversize behavior

This section directly affects screen size, field positions, and recording reliability.

docs.title: Automation/Startup
docs.text:
Controls startup and command automation behavior.

Includes:

  • Exec command override
  • Login macro
  • HTTPD binding
  • Minimum required s3270 version

Use this for scripted startup flows and custom launch behavior.

docs.title: Diagnostics
docs.text:
Controls trace and diagnostic output.

Includes:

  • Trace enable/disable
  • Trace file and max size
  • Help/version/unit-test environment flags

Use this section when troubleshooting host interaction issues.

docs.title: App
docs.text:
Controls application-level UI features.

Includes:

  • Allow log access
  • Use keypad (show virtual keypad by default)

Use this section to control log visibility and default keyboard UI behavior.

docs.title: Chaos
docs.text:
Controls chaos exploration defaults.

Includes:

  • CHAOS_MAX_STEPS
  • CHAOS_TIME_BUDGET_SEC
  • CHAOS_STEP_DELAY_SEC
  • CHAOS_SEED
  • CHAOS_MAX_FIELD_LENGTH
  • CHAOS_OUTPUT_FILE
  • CHAOS_EXCLUDE_NO_PROGRESS_EVENTS

Use this section to tune how aggressively chaos mode explores screens and where optional output should be written.

docs.title: Log Access
docs.text:
If log access is enabled in settings, you can open the Logs modal from the toolbar and:

  • Turn verbose logging on/off
  • Refresh logs
  • Copy/download logs
  • Clear logs

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
• Keep one known-good model/code page profile per host environment.
  • Apply TLS changes carefully and verify certificate paths.
  • Prefer debug playback for new recordings before running full play mode.

docs.title: Keyboard and Controls
docs.text: This page explains toolbar controls, keyboard mappings, and the virtual keypad.

docs.title: Toolbar Controls
docs.text:
Main toolbar actions include:

  • Disconnect session
  • View logs
  • Open settings
  • Start/stop recording
  • Load recording
  • Play/debug/view/remove recording
  • Playback pause/resume/stop controls (when active)

docs.title: Virtual Keyboard (Keypad)
docs.text:
Use the keyboard icon to show or hide the virtual keypad.

Keypad features:

  • Compact and full modes
  • PF keys (PF1 to PF24)
  • PA keys (PA1 to PA3)
  • Common editing/navigation keys
  • Dedicated Hide button

The keypad visibility preference can be saved in Settings (Use keypad).

  1. Keypad title area
  2. Compact/full mode toggle
  3. Hide keypad
  4. PF key groups
  5. PA key group
  6. Common 3270 action keys

docs.title: Physical Keyboard Mappings
docs.text:
Common mappings used by 3270Web:

  • Enter -> Enter
  • Tab -> Tab
  • Shift+Tab -> BackTab
  • Esc -> Clear
  • Arrow keys -> Cursor movement
  • Home -> Home
  • Backspace -> BackSpace
  • Delete -> Delete
  • Insert -> Insert
  • F1..F12 -> PF1..PF12
  • Shift+F1..Shift+F12 -> PF13..PF24
  • Alt+F1 -> PA1
  • Alt+F2 -> PA2
  • Alt+F3 -> PA3

Additional 3270 actions available in keypad/full mappings include Reset, EraseEOF, EraseInput, Dup, FieldMark, SysReq, Attn, and NewLine.

docs.title: Focus and Input Behavior
docs.text: When you press mapped keys, 3270Web sends the action to the host and refreshes the terminal content. Cursor-aware behavior is preserved for field input where possible.

docs.title: Tips for Reliable Use
docs.text:
• Keep browser focus on the terminal area while typing.
  • Use the keypad for less common 3270 keys if your keyboard layout does not expose them.
  • If commands appear out of sync, pause briefly and retry in debug playback mode.

docs.title: Screen Size and Model Guide
docs.text: 3270 screen size depends on the terminal model in use.

docs.title: Model Sizes
docs.text: Model Rows Columns Typical use 2 24 80 Standard 3270 screens 3 32 80 Extra rows 4 43 80 Large-screen workflows 5 27 132 Wide-screen workflows

docs.title: Why This Matters
docs.text:
Your model affects:

  • How much of a screen is visible
  • Cursor coordinates used in recordings
  • Compatibility with host applications that expect a specific size

If a host app expects 24x80, use Model 2 unless instructed otherwise.

docs.title: Choosing a Model
docs.text:
Set your model in configuration or .env.

Example:

S3270_MODEL=2

Alternative values are also accepted (for example 3279-4-E).

docs.title: Practical Guidance
docs.text:
• When recordings fail at FillString coordinates, confirm the same model is active.
  • Keep the same model across environments (dev/test/prod) for reliable playback.
  • If text alignment looks wrong, check both model and code page settings.

docs.title: Recordings and Playback
docs.text: 3270Web can capture terminal actions as JSON recordings and run them later.

docs.title: Recording and Playback Callouts
docs.text:
1. Start recording
  2. Play recording
  3. Debug recording
  4. View recording JSON
  5. Remove loaded recording
  6. Workflow status indicator/widget

docs.title: Record a Session
docs.text:
1. Connect to the target host.
  2. Click Start recording.
  3. Perform your terminal actions.
  4. Click Stop recording.
  5. Optional: click Download to save the generated JSON file.

docs.title: Load a Recording
docs.text:
1. Click Load recording.
  2. Choose a .json file.
  3. Confirm the filename appears as loaded in the toolbar.
  4. Click View recording to inspect the full JSON.

docs.title: Play a Recording
docs.text:
1. Load a recording.
  2. Click Play recording.
  3. Watch playback status in the toolbar and Workflow Status widget.
  4. Use Pause/Resume in play mode if needed.
  5. Click Stop playback to end execution.

docs.title: Debug a Recording (Step-by-step)
docs.text:
1. Load a recording.
  2. Click Debug recording.
  3. Use Step to execute one action at a time.
  4. Watch current step number/type in the status indicators.
  5. Click Stop playback when done.

Debug mode is recommended for new or edited recordings.

docs.title: Remove a Loaded Recording
docs.text: Click Remove recording to clear the currently loaded file from the session.

docs.title: Workflow Status Widget
docs.text:
The Workflow Status panel shows:

  • Current step and total steps
  • Current action type
  • Delay range and applied delay (when present)
  • Recent playback events

You can:

  • Open it from the status indicator
  • Minimize/maximize it
  • Enable or disable tracking

docs.title: Recording JSON Basics
docs.text:
A recording includes a Steps array of actions.

Example:

{
  "Host": "sampleapp:app1",
  "Steps": [
    { "Type": "Connect" },
    {
      "Type": "FillString",
      "Coordinates": { "Row": 5, "Column": 21 },
      "Text": "User"
    },
    { "Type": "PressEnter" },
    { "Type": "Disconnect" }
  ]
}

Common action types:

  • FillString
  • PressEnter
  • PressTab
  • PressPF<n> (for example PressPF3)

docs.title: Troubleshooting Playback
docs.text:
• Confirm host and port are correct.
  • Confirm terminal model matches the one used when recording.
  • Confirm screen layout and field coordinates still match host screens.
  • Add delays for timing-sensitive screens.
  • Use Debug mode to find the first failing step.

docs.title: Related: Chaos Exploration
docs.text:
Use Chaos mode when you need to discover unknown screen paths or generate new workflow steps automatically.

  • Start/stop chaos from the toolbar
  • Review granular attempt status in the Workflow Status widget
  • Export the generated JSON and load it back as a standard workflow

See Chaos Mode for full details.
